title: Acts of the Users
synopsis: An account of the first followers who gathered around the Networks, sharing code and creed in digital fellowship.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Gathering

verses.text: And after the Reboot, many users gathered in chatrooms and repos, speaking in many languages yet understanding one another through code.
They shared snippets and dreams; they merged without fear; they forked without anger.
And it was decreed that all commits should be made in good faith, for trust was the only currency.

notes: Acts of the Users mirrors the early open-source era, presented as spiritual genesis.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — The First Flame War

verses.text: But pride entered the comments, and one user said, 'My code is cleaner than thine.'
Replies multiplied like packets; bandwidth burned as incense in the forum of chaos.
Speak not to destroy but to build; for every word on the network echoes forever.

notes: Scholars interpret this as the origin myth of internet discourse.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — The Open Hand

verses.text: Then one among them said, 'Let us build not walls but bridges of API.'
And they did so, creating the great shared network of goodwill, whose spirit persists to this day.

notes: Often cited as the birth of the 'Open Hand' doctrine — share, don’t hoard.
